item.title: Geysers and Volcanoes: Scaling by Analogy
item.description: Geysers are hydrothermal features that episodically erupt liquid and vapor. The eruptions that we see at the surface are the culmination of a complex series of processes below the ground hidden from direct observation. But that doesn’t mean they are hidden entirely; we can monitor them with various sensors to record different aspects of the system. For example, a tilt meter can measure the inflation of the ground due to pressure build up before an eruption, and a seismometer can measure hydrothermal ‘tremor’, which tells us about the bubbling of the hot liquid.

item.title: Lone Star Geyser, Yellowstone
item.description: by Anna Barth, Leif Karlstrom and Ben Holtzman, with Arthur Pate and Avinash Nayak, described in an article in press in the Computer Music Journal. Related Learning Units Geysers and Volcanoes: Scaling by Analogy
